Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 9896eaed88332eca7334a564a2ea2e0baf135639
The overall approach looks good to me.
Redfish currently only allows a 4-digit year.
where does this math come from? Did you write them yourself, or referenced some doc somewhere?
I wish I could say I'm that smart.  ACK, will fix.   I need to note where this came from.
Cited the source of these calculations.
nit: suggest adding "due to binary code size"
It's arguably more for compile times;  Binary size is about the same, but ACK.
Just wondering, any reason for using "class" for IntType vs "typename" for Period?
Good point, I should be consistent.  ACK.
Can you help me understand in what kind of cases we'd have d > t?
For dates before 1970 is my understanding from looking at this code.

"from looking at this code." >> did you look at some outside code?

I still don't quite understand how this if-statement works but I trust that it does work since unit tests pass.

> "from looking at this code." >> did you look at some outside code?

No, looking at this code.  The thing here is that negative dates are prior to 1970-01-01, so we need to account for negative "days" being actually one day prior

ie, 1 second before epoch, is actually 1 day before epoch, because we need 1969-12-31, so this line accounts for that.

> 
> I still don't quite understand how this if-statement works but I trust that it does work since unit tests pass.

With that said, now that we don't handle negative dates (we just clamp to epoch) I don't think this line is useful, so I've removed it.
For Redfish (Redfish spec 1.15.1, 9.5.5 Date-Time) we need a version of the ISO 8061 extended string where the year is exactly 4 digits, but this can return more than that.
Yep, same comment as before, ACK.
Yep.  it's a missing include that this file got transitively through posix_time.hpp.
nit: looks nicer if this is on the next line :)
May be worth mentioning in the header comment that "pad" also serves as the exact width and we don't do negatives
It does handle negative numbers, though. Treating them as positive numbers?

The std::abs is left over from another variation;  I've removed it, but regardless, treating them as positive numbers is certainly not the "correct" behavior.

I've removed std::abs to make that behavior more clear.
nit: move val inside the for loop?
A question, do you invent this?
Is this function worth a highlevel description and a couple of examples about output given certain input?

Considering this is in details, I generally try to put the documentation on the public facing functions, which is below.  That encourages users to use the intended overloads, and not the details functions.

Yep, this is written basically from scratch.  I wasn't really able to find one that handled all the constraints we had cleanly.  The call leading up to civilFromDays is taken from the civilFromDays docs, but that is already referenced.
This is not a constraint previously, but not a big deal since we won't likely have a use case where time is before the epoch.

Yep, that was my thinking as well.  I can't think of a use case where negative dates are required, and technically all our interfaces are defined as "time SINCE epoch", so I think negative should be fine.
Been in review for a couple weeks, pretty sure the folks that have had an opinion here have commented, merging.
